awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Vivid Pixel array for Reflective, Full-color Digital signage
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project evaluates the feasibility of constructing vivid, full-color, reflective display modules for large-area outdoor digital signage driven by dielectric elastomers suitable for pilot testing.  Completion of Phase II objectives is expected to have the following impact:  Commercially, the availability of new signage products will create significant economic impact through partial capture of the $14.2B domestic billboard and sign manufacturing market.  Up to 10% of US zoning codes are estimated to prohibit LED-based (light emitting diode) signage while potentially permitting a reflective digital signage technology, expanding the domestic market up to $5.6B, with a 10x impact worldwide.  Environmentally, greenhouse gas reduction is expected as an alternative to LED-based technology; up to 40x reduction in energy consumption is anticipated relative to LEDs. Additionally, billboard wrap waste will be reduced by replacing printed signage. Scientifically, the use of dielectric elastomers as a class of materials in products would be promoted through addressing technological and manufacturing hurdles currently limiting market translation. Societally, increased impact from timely public service announcements on digital billboards displayed during natural disasters, when catching fugitives from the FBI?s Most Wanted lists, and with Amber/Silver alerts are expected through large-area digital sign proliferation.

In phase II, electroactive polymer-based proof-of-concept display modules will be constructed and tested, ready for pilot testing with initial customers.  The low-cost display design uses unique electro-hydraulic driving principles to enable exceptional refractive index matching within the optical stack for highly vivid and reflective full-color generation.  In phase I, a functional proof-of-concept pixel array module was fabricated using scalable processes.  To achieve pilot readiness, improvements in performance, resolution, and calibration to meet advertiser standards are needed, as well as environmental qualification for outdoor operation, development of industry-conscious software control, and qualification of supply chain inputs to enable further production at scale.  Phase II research will address these technical challenges by introducing process refinements and quality control standards, conduct color calibration using existing techniques, perform industry-relevant environmental testing, work with vendors to source soft-tooled components, and develop module and multi-module control software.  The result of phase II efforts will be a calibrated and rugged one square foot, full-color, 16mm pitch, reflective display module ready for scaling to pilot production following phase II.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) phase II award resulted in significant advancement of a unique, fluid-based reflective display technology with applications as a low-power, light-pollution free alternative to large-area LED signage.  Commercially, first 2-color units are set for installation with a customer in the next quarter. We anticipate deploying reflective fluidic display products in multiple markets, including Fuel Pricers, On-Premise Digital Signage, Billboards, Traffic Safety, and others.  Full-color systems are in development to expand our market offerings, leveraging learnings and regulatory precedent gained from a 2-color product launch.

This award enabled Solchroma to address the most fundamental technical challenges in designing and manufacturing the high-performance ‘electro-hydraulic’ fluidic display technology.  Pixel structural design, materials processing, environmental testing, electrical control, actuator development, ink development, assembly, and other critical areas were advanced significantly during the award period, resulting in the construction of functional 2-color sign systems.  The award and technical development catalyzed funding from multiple other entities, including an institutional venture investor. 

Environmentally, Solchroma’s displays reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions when replacing less-efficient outdoor LED systems.  While relative GHG reduction depends significantly on the usage model, 2-color Solchroma systems in initial Fuel Pricer applications can reduce total power consumption to less than 10% of a comparable LED solution including frontlighting, with the potential to prevent GHG emissions on the order of 100k metric tons/year when extrapolated to the full US market.

Scientifically, dielectric elastomer actuators were explored in great detail to drive fluidic displays, including the creation of unique, low-cost, high voltage array-driving electronics.  However, several business considerations drove a decision to make Solchroma’s system actuator-agnostic and initially adopt other actuator technologies.  Further maturity of dielectric elastomer actuator technology could warrant a revisit in the future.  Several patent applications were filed as an outcome of the award covering technical developments, including the use of dielectric elastomers in Solchroma’s system and related innovations.

Societally, greater access to non-LED digital signage alternatives will increase resident quality of life by minimizing light pollution.  Additionally, government and private entities will be able to communicate more easily with the public using a large-area format.  We anticipate increasing the impact from timely public safety announcements and Silver/Amber alerts as an outcome of Solchroma product dissemination. 

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2022
Modified by: Roger M Diebold

Image
  • Solchroma's cuttlefish-inspired reflective fluidic displays pump liquid ink in and out of view to create optical contrast. Having exceptional refractive index matching, these low-power and light-pollution free displays are well suited for applications in uncontrolled lighting environments.
    Solchroma Technologies, Inc.
    Roger M Diebold
    High performance reflective fluidic display
